'''Impairment of 2 or 3 blood lines'' (anaemia, thrombocytopenia, neutropenia) on the haemogram requires a myelogram before any specific treatment as it suggests a bone marrow cause for the cytopenias. Circulating blastosis is not necessary for a myelogram to be indicated.

This will show > 25% blasts on rich MO in the case of acute leukaemia. This examination should be systematically supplemented by CSF analysis, even in the absence of any neurological symptoms.

question.title: When is a myelogram indicated in children with acute leukaemia?
question.description: A child is diagnosed with acute leukaemia and has impairment of 2 or 3 blood lines (anaemia, thrombocytopenia, neutropenia). What is the next step?

option_a.title: Perform a bone marrow biopsy
option_a.description: A bone marrow biopsy is necessary to confirm the diagnosis of acute leukaemia

option_b.title: Perform a CSF analysis and a bone marrow biopsy
option_b.description: Both CSF analysis and a bone marrow biopsy are necessary to confirm the diagnosis of acute leukaemia

option_c.title: Perform a myelogram and a bone marrow biopsy
option_c.description: A myelogram is sufficient to diagnose acute leukaemia, but a bone marrow biopsy is not necessary

option_d.title: Perform a bone marrow biopsy and a CT scan
option_d.description: A bone marrow biopsy and a CT scan are necessary to confirm the diagnosis of acute leukaemia
